image.altText: A man with glasses and a navy blue suit and tie stands behind a lecturn at a business conference

props.synopsis: In his first broadcast interview since ACCC allegations became public, Qantas chairman Richard Goyder maintains he has the confidence of the board and says major investors want him to stay.

title.children: 'We know we've let people down': Qantas chairman dodges calls to quit

image.altText: Tennis fans cool off at the Australian Open.

props.synopsis: As Australia prepares for hot and dry months after the declaration of an El Niño, a stark reminder of the increasing danger posed by heatwaves in Australia's southern cities may lie ahead.

title.children: El Niño is likely to bring a scorching summer. These cities might feel it most

image.altText: The silhouette of a power station is seen against the sky in the early evening, with thick smoke billowing from three towers.

props.synopsis: There are growing safety concerns at Yallourn Power Station in Victoria, one of Australia's biggest coal-fired power plants. Experts say that could be bad news heading into a long, hot summer.

title.children: Dark clouds gather over one of Australia's biggest coal plants as El Niño heats the land

image.altText: Anthony Albanese putting on a mask at a press conference.

props.synopsis: An inquiry into government response to the COVID-19 pandemic has been announced, but state and territory local lockdowns and border closures are likely to avoid scrutiny.

title.children: Lockdowns and border closures omitted in scope of inquiry into government COVID-19 pandemic response

image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

props.synopsis: A new COVID variant nicknamed "Pirola" has been detected in Australia after sparking a sped-up vaccination program in the United Kingdom.

title.children: The 'highly mutated' COVID variant BA.2.86 — known as Pirola — has landed in Australia

image.altText: Senior man wearing a shirt receives an injection in his arm.

props.synopsis: If it has been six months or longer since you last had a COVID-19 infection or a vaccine dose, you are eligible for a jab. Here's what you need to know before getting one.

title.children: A new COVID-19 virus has been detected onshore. So is it time to get a booster?

image.altText: an aboriginal man wearing traditional dress

props.synopsis: A respected religious leader from north-east Arnhem Land wants the No campaign to retract his image from its campaign material and publicly announce that it has done so.

title.children: 'No consent': Arnhem Land elder calls for Fair Australia to retract his image from campaign material

image.altText: An aerial photo of a line of fire along foliage in the desert

props.synopsis: As ranger groups in the NT's Top End use funding from carbon credits to prepare for a tough bushfire season, groups in the desert are calling for access to the same scheme.

title.children: Top End rangers are funding fire mitigation with carbon credits. Why can't it be done in the desert?

props.synopsis: Five years ago, LeBron James set out to fix some of America's most difficult problems. Some question whether the project is living up to its promises.

title.children: LeBron James set out to revolutionise America’s broken school system. Then the results came in

image.altText: Old newspaper articles

props.synopsis: The deadline for the final report into unsolved deaths suspected of being LGBTIQ hate crimes in NSW has been extended after police delayed providing crucial documents.

title.children: NSW Police need 900 years to clear backlog of unsolved homicides, gay hate inquiry told

image.altText: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy addresses a high level Security Council meeting.

props.synopsis: Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy takes the floor at the UN Security Council to lash 'criminal' Russia before foreign secretary Sergei Lavrov unloads for Russia.

title.children: As Russia ignores Zelenskyy at UN, Ukraine calls for stripping of Russia's veto power

image.altText: Lindsay May looking up at the camera holding a painted abalone shell

props.synopsis: As debate over the Voice continues around the country, locals in this remote South Australian community are focused on issues closer to home.

title.children: This town only has enough jobs for 15 per cent of locals. The community is working to change that

image.altText: An Indonesian woman crying with her hand at her face.

props.synopsis: In the latest series of cases involving blasphemy laws in Indonesia, a TikToker with more than than 2 million followers is found guilty and jailed for two years for saying an Islamic phrase before eating crispy pork skin.

title.children: Woman jailed for two years and fined $25,000 for eating pork on TikTok in Indonesia

image.altText: Airbnb logo on a pink background with silhouetted figurines of travellers with bags in the foreground

props.synopsis: If there's a lesson from the evolution of the gig economy, it's that we don't yet know how AI will disrupt our economy and our lives. But it's at least worth considering potential impacts and contemplating sensible rules of the road early on, writes David Speers.

title.children: Eight years ago, Airbnb was a new platform with a hidden dark side. Now the warnings are sounding again

image.altText: To young men look at camera and make hand signs. One of their faces in blurred

props.synopsis: The court heard Josiah Binsaris allegedly broke into a woman’s home along with two other assailants and brutally assaulted her and her partner, while cloaked in a mask.

title.children: Former Don Dale inmate refused bail over alleged home invasion, weeks after $220k payout

image.altText: Screenshot of Bob Ross with the Walk in the Woods painting during the first episode of his TV series.

props.synopsis: The painting is on sale after spending almost four decades hanging in a TV station volunteer's home.

title.children: First painting from Bob Ross's TV series goes on sale for more than $15m

image.altText: A Cambodian woman holds a sign reading "Pay your workers".

props.synopsis: The women making clothes and shoes for some of the world's biggest brands have seen their wages drop and are spiralling into debt, even as fashion companies see revenues rise, according to a new report.

title.children: They make clothes for the biggest sporting brands in the world. But these women are spiralling in debt distress

image.altText: Von der Leyen can be seen in focus in between soldiers

props.synopsis: A former musician who was once forced to go into hiding from terrorists, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen's path to power has been an incredible journey.

title.children: How a young girl destined to become a 'housewife at the side of a powerful man' instead grew up to lead Europe through crisis

image.altText: Shane Drumgold holding a folder walking into ACAT.

props.synopsis: The inquiry into the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann delivered a scathing assessment of Shane Drumgold, prompting the former DPP to launch legal action.

title.children: Victorian judge to oversee former top prosecutor's legal challenge against ACT government

image.altText: Writers and supporters holding up signs such as "Writers Guild of America on Strike!" and "It didn't have to be this way"

props.synopsis: Writers and producers could soon reach an agreement to end the writers strike, according to sources, following a meeting with top Hollywood executives.

title.children: 'Positive sign': Hollywood writers talk with studios in hopes of ending strike

image.altText: A fair-haired Italian man and a dark-haired Italian man sit on rocks in a mountainous landscape eating bread with their hands.

props.synopsis: This Cannes Jury Prize-winning film set in the scenic Italian Alps is travel-porn worthy – but its central narrative about friendship and the loss of youthful idealism has clout.

title.children: 'Handsome Italians in chunky knitwear': This award-winning, wistful film oozes rustic chic

image.altText: A teenage boy and girl, dressed in colourful clothes, walk their bikes as they chat outside school.

props.synopsis: The British sex comedy has portrayed the teenage experience with nuance and humour. Here's everything you need to know before pressing play on the final season.

title.children: The final season of Sex Education has arrived. Here's everything you need to know before saying goodbye

image.altText: Blonde lady in a colorful top leaning next to a window.

props.synopsis: Pain management trial researcher Natasha Brice says Ballarat is leading Australia in the number of patients taking part in a global ketamine study.

title.children: Thousands sign up for ketamine trial to wipe out chronic surgical pain

image.altText: a man in an office with documents

props.synopsis: The ASX sheds 1 per cent in line with global markets after the US central bank stiffens its hawkish stance, while former ACCC chair Fels probes price gouging. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX sheds 1pc, former ACCC chair Fels probes price gouging, US interest rates unchanged

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX 200 lost 1.3 per cent today. The index never really stood a chance, after the US Federal Reserve indicated last night its fight against inflation isn't over. ASX 200 top 5: Data #3 +3.01% Link Administration +2.95% Paladin Energy +2.08% Deterra Royalties + 2.07% Alumina +1.51% ASX 200 bottom 5: Sayona Mining -11.43% Weebit Nano -4.80% Block -4.76% Alkem -4.59% IGO -4.11% Ours was not the only stock exchange in our region in decline today. Some of the below exchanges were still trading at 4pm AEST when I collated these numbers. Nikkei -1.2% Hang Seng -1.2% SSE Composite -0.6% Kospi -1.7% NZ S & P 50 -0.1%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Losses on ASX widespread

children.content: The ASX 200 lost 1.3 per cent today.
The index never really stood a chance, after the US Federal Reserve indicated last night its fight against inflation isn't over.
Ours was not the only stock exchange in our region in decline today. Some of the below exchanges were still trading at 4pm AEST when I collated these numbers.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's competition watchdog has blocked Toll operator Transurban from a cquiring Melbourne's Eastlink toll road from Horizon Roads. The ACCC ruled that if the company was allowed to buy the almost 40-kilometre stretch of toll road in Victoria's east, it would substantially lessen competition for future toll roads in Victoria. Transurban operates almost every private sector toll road in the country, including City Link in Melbourne and the new West Gate Tunnel, to be opened in 2025. ACCC Chair Gina Cass-Gottlieb said if the deal was approved, Transurban would hold a monopoly on the country's toll roads. "Horizon roads is the only other private toll operator in Victoria and in Australia," she said. "If this proceeds, Transurban would be the only one." It's the first time the ACCC has blocked Transurban. In a statement to the ASX, the company said it was disappointed and was closely reviewing the decision. Find the ACCC's work on the matter here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Transurban blocked from acquiring Melbourne's Eastlink toll road

featuredLink.title: Transurban Group proposed acquisition of Horizon Roads Pty Ltd

children.content: cquiring Melbourne's Eastlink toll road from Horizon Roads
The ACCC ruled that if the company was allowed to buy the almost 40-kilometre stretch of toll road in Victoria's east, it
would substantially lessen competition for future toll roads in Victoria.
Transurban operates almost every private sector toll road in the country, including City Link in Melbourne and the new West Gate Tunnel, to be opened in 2025.
ACCC Chair Gina Cass-Gottlieb said if the deal was approved, Transurban would hold a monopoly on the country's toll roads.
"Horizon roads is the only other private toll operator in Victoria and in Australia," she said.
"If this proceeds, Transurban would be the only one."
It's the first time the ACCC has blocked Transurban.
In a statement to the ASX, the company said it was disappointed and was closely reviewing the decision.
Find the ACCC's work on the matter here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We're heading into the last minutes of trade, so here's a snapshot. The ASX 200 is down 1.34% Bottom 5 Sayona Mining -10.95% Capricorn Metals -5.11% Alkem -4.92% Block -4.73% Weebit Nano -4.8% Top 5 Data #3 +2.58% Link Administration +2.2% Paladin +2.1% Deterra Royalties + 2.1% South 32 +1.8%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Final stretch of trade

children.content: We're heading into the last minutes of trade, so here's a snapshot.

image.altText: Sufjan Stevens performing at the 2018 Academy Awards ceremony.

props.synopsis: The alternative musician is facing a long recovery after being diagnosed with Guillain-Barré syndrome.

title.children: 'I woke up one morning and couldn't walk': Sufjan Stevens diagnosed with rare autoimmune disease

image.altText: Bomb remains in dirt next to small signs with skull and crossbones on them.

props.synopsis: In a letter to the US government, a UN torture expert says cluster munitions — which are prohibited by more than 100 countries — "indiscriminately and seriously injure civilians both at the time of use and in post-conflict" and should not be used.

title.children: US urged not to give Ukraine cluster munitions which could 'remain dangerous for decades'

image.altText: The six politicians stand in front of the US Capitol building.

props.synopsis: An unlikely coalition of Australian parliamentarians converges on Washington to lobby US decision-makers to drop the legal pursuit of Julian Assange and grant his freedom by Christmas.

title.children: Julian Assange unites cross-party delegation in Washington to push for WikiLeaks founder's freedom

image.altText: An Aboriginal man with curly blonde hair smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: Wiradjuri and Birpai elders are concerned about a lack of information and education on the Voice to Parliament referendum. As older generations struggle to understand, younger leaders take up the challenge of educating the community.

title.children: 'Tell it like a story': Voice referendum sessions to better inform Indigenous elders led by youth

image.altText: Electricians place solar panels on roof

props.synopsis: The country is transitioning through the largest building code changes in a decade. But what does this mean for home owners?

title.children: Building your dream home? Here's what you'll need to consider under new construction code changes

image.altText: Kylie Minogue wearing a red dress and long red gloves, looking away from the camera with hand on hip and longish blonde hair

props.synopsis: Australia's pop princess Kylie Minogue has been nominated for four ARIAs. If she wins at least one, it will be her first ARIA in more than two decades.

title.children: If Kylie Minogue wins a 2023 ARIA, it will be her first in more than 20 years

image.altText: The silhouette of a firefighter is seen in front of a large bushfire burning high into trees.

props.synopsis: Catastrophic fire danger warnings have been issued in parts of Australia already as it enters a hotter and drier than average climate pattern. If the fire season has taken you by surprise, here's a reminder of how the warning system works.

title.children: What makes a bushfire alert 'catastrophic', and how should you respond?

image.altText: Wind turbines are set to dot the landscape in Victoria's west

props.synopsis: Some experts are warning Australia's ambitions to have zero carbon emissions by 2050 need to be scaled up dramatically.

title.children: Reaching net zero by 2035 would take a 'gargantuan' effort. But these experts say our current 2050 target is just too far away

image.altText: A composite image of Darcy Moore (left) and Erin Phillips.

props.synopsis: The five-year collective bargaining agreement covering male and female players features significant wage rises and a longer AFLW season.

title.children: AFL strikes $2.2 billion pay deal with players in historic joint collective bargaining agreement

image.altText: Man in a suit stands for his bail hearing in front of a crowd of photograpers.

props.synopsis: Oscar Pistorius was eligible for parole in March and the double-amputee Olympic runner may have been wrongly denied early release from prison because of an error.

title.children: Oscar Pistorius may have been wrongly denied parole over error
